results.title: The Glenrowan affair
results.creator_credit: Australian Motion Pictures and Rupert Kathner
results.brief_description: This film, based on the Ned Kelly legend, was filmed in and around Benalla by a specialist in low budget quickies with a local football hero, Bob Chitty as Ned. Told from the perspective of an ageing Dan Kelly in present day Benalla, the narrative is presented as a factual retelling of the exploits of the Kelly gang despite its obvious embellishment of the Kelly myth. The shortcomings of the script and its clumsy realisation were derided by the Benalla audience at its premiere and noted by press reviewers upon its brief Sydney release. Narrated by Charles Tingwell. Cast includes: Bob Chitty, Albie Henderson, Ben Crowe, Bill Wright, John Fernside, Chas. Tasman, Charles Webb, Edward Smith, Frank Ransom, Stan Tolhurst. Photography, Harry Malcolm ; editor, Alex Ezard ; sound, Berry Hallett.

results.title: The Glenn Miller story
results.creator_credit: Aaron Rosenberg, Universal International Pictures and Anthony Mann
results.brief_description: This bio-pic is the story of legendary (real-life) American big band leader Glenn Miller. Miller was a visionary who introduced swing music to American audiences in the 1940s with his own original compositions. Starting in the 1930s “The Glen Miller story” tracks Miller’s struggles to have his arrangements played when the mood of the day was for the standards only. Miller was a talented trombonist who was driven by a love of music to champion the case for a new style of writing. The film also tells the story of Miller wooing his teenage sweetheart, whom he eventually marries. Helen (June Allyson) frequently played second fiddle to Miller’s ambitions, even spending her wedding night at a club whilst Miller jammed with Louis Armstrong. The film features many musicians of the era playing themselves which greatly enhances its appeal. Musicians include: Louis Armstrong, Gene Krupa, Barney Biggard, Arvell Shaw and Frances Langford. “The Glenn Miller story” was one of the most successful bio-pics of its day. Starring James Stewart as Miller, the film was nominated for five Academy Awards in 1954, winning one for best sound.

results.title: The Gleaners and I = Les Glaneurs et la glaneuse
results.brief_description: To ‘glean’ is to gather after the harvest. Gleaners are therefore those who collect potatoes and the like that remain after the harvest to survive. This documentary written, directed and narrated by Agnes Varda, shot with a digital camera, is an engrossing and intimate look at scavengers in the French countryside. We see the traditional gleaners, as immortalised in the paintings of Millet and Van Gogh, and then the present day gleaners living and surviving on what they can find. This award winning documentary is touching and presents us with food for thought.

results.title: The Glass house
results.creator_credit: Rick Rosenberg, Robert W. Christiansen, Tomorrow Entertainment and Tom Gries
results.brief_description: Adapted for television from a short story by Truman Capote and Wyatt Cooper, “The Glass house” gives an inside view of prison life and the prison system in one of America’s toughest prisons and is filmed entirely on location at Utah State Prison. Although the story and characters are completely fictitious, the situations are based on real-life experiences with most of the background faces and voices being those of actual prisoners. The story begins with several new inmates, including a college professor, Jonathan Paige (Alan Alda) and a rather young and naive teenager, Allan Campbell (Kristoffer Tabori), going through the processes of prison induction. However it is not long before Paige and Campbell are approached by the rather brutal and sadistic gang boss in the prison, Hugo Slocum (Vic Morrow) and each has to make his own choice as to which road he will take. Violence, corruption, drugs, rape and intimidation are all part of the prison “game”, even to the point where the prison guards and the warden can be paid by the gang leaders to turn a blind eye to attacks on individual prisoners. Only the new prison guard (Clu Gulager), full of ideals and good intentions can provide any hope to this corrupt and brutal system. “The Glass house” is a grim reminder of the psychological and physical abuse which takes place inside prisons and to director Tom Gries’ credit, the film is presented in a realistic style, containing some violence necessary to the story, but not glorified or over-the-top as in some of the action movies of today. (Awards: Nominated Best Movie Made for TV in the 1973 Golden Globe Awards; San Sebastian International Film Festival) Cast also includes Dean Jagger and Billy Dee Williams.

results.title: The Glacier climbers
results.brief_description: The story of a four day mountain journey from Westland to Canterbury across the Southern Alps. At Malte Brun Hut the climbers meet Sir Edmund Hillary and the parties combine for the last stage of the journey down the Tasman Glacier to the Hermitage, Mount Cook. Includes some spectacular mountain scenes.

results.title: The Giving tree (K)
results.creator_credit: Stephen Bosustow Productions, Nick Bosustow, Shel Silverstein and Charlie O. Hayward
results.brief_description: This poignant story about the relationships between a boy and a tree illustrates some truths about the meaning of giving, receiving and love. the tree unselfishly offers itself to the boy for climbing, for shade and for pleasure. But as the boy grows up his life takes him further and further away from the tree. But old age brings their relationship full circle. Based on the book by Shel Silverstein. Music and narration by Shel Silverstein. Animation by Charlie O. Hayward.

results.title: The Girls and daddy
results.creator_credit: American Mutoscope and Biograph Company and D.W. Griffith
results.brief_description: Melodrama by D.W. Griffith about two young ladies and a burglar. The film is presented in two parts: first, the scenes in the order in which they were photographed, and then as edited. The first part is silent, and the second has a musical accompaniment. Cast includes David Miles, Florence Lawrence, Dorothy West, Mack Sennett.

results.title: The Girl who spelled freedom
results.creator_credit: R.W. Goodwin, Walt Disney Productions and Simon Wincer
results.brief_description: Based on newspaper articles and personal interviews with Linn Yann, this moving film tells of one young Cambodian girl refugees experiences in America and her fight to be accepted. With the support of her caring American sponsors (played by Mary Kay Place and Wayne Rogers), Linn Yann (Jade Chinn) overcomes the strangeness of her new country and makes a name for herself by winning the regional spelling competition, thus bringing attention to the plight of other refugees like her.

results.title: The Girl who met Simone de Beauvoir in Paris
results.creator_credit: Richard Brennan, Richard Wherrett and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Regarded as one of Australia’s acclaimed theatre and artistic directors, Richard Wherrett has transformed his directing skills into film with this adaptation of “The Girl who met Simone de Beauvoir in Paris. Cast includes Tony Llewellyn-Jones, Judy Morris, Anna Volska and John Clayton. Director of Photography, Geoff Burton.
